Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the impact of the Health Maintenance Organization Act of 1973 by stating that it changed everything and allowed for-profit healthcare.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that it was illegal to profit from healthcare before the 1973 HMO act.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the development of for-profit healthcare was solely due to the HMO act, ignoring other factors such as the growth of employer-sponsored health insurance.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert provides an alternative explanation by stating that for-profit health care existed prior to 1973 and that the HMO act did not create or enable that phenomenon.
